column2: Even if it were wrong, said Mrs. Wilkins, "it would only be for a month."
column3: Even if it were wrong, said mrs Wilkins, "it would only be for a month."

column2: That-- began Mrs. Arbuthnot, quite clear as to the reprehensibleness of such a point of view; but Mrs. Wilkins stopped her before she could finish.
column3: That- began mrs Arbuthnot, quite clear as to the reprehensibleness of such a point of view; but mrs Wilkins stopped her before she could finish.

column2: Anyhow, said Mrs. Wilkins, stopping her, "I'm sure it's wrong to go on being good for too long, till one gets miserable.
column3: Anyhow, said mrs Wilkins, stopping her, "I'm sure it's wrong to go on being good for too long, till one gets miserable.

column2: And I can see you've been good for years and years, because you look so unhappy"-- Mrs. Arbuthnot opened her mouth to protest--"and I--I've done nothing but duties, things for other people, ever since I was a girl, and I don't believe anybody loves me a bit--a bit--the b-better--and I long-- oh, I long--for something else--something else--"
column3: And I can see you've been good for years and years, because you look so unhappy"-- mrs Arbuthnot opened her mouth to protest-"and I-I've done nothing but duties, things for other people, ever since I was a girl, and I don't believe anybody loves me a bit-a bit-the b better-and I long- oh, I long-for something else-something else-"

column2: Was she going to cry?
column3: Was she going to cry?

column2: Mrs. Arbuthnot became acutely uncomfortable and sympathetic.
column3: mrs Arbuthnot became acutely uncomfortable and sympathetic.

column2: She hoped she wasn't going to cry.
column3: She hoped she wasn't going to cry.

column2: Not there.
column3: Not there.

column2: Not in that unfriendly room, with strangers coming and going.
column3: Not in that unfriendly room, with strangers coming and going.

column2: But Mrs. Wilkins, after tugging agitatedly at a handkerchief that wouldn't come out of her pocket, did succeed at last in merely apparently blowing her nose with it, and then, blinking her eyes very quickly once or twice, looked at Mrs. Arbuthnot with a quivering air of half humble, half frightened apology, and smiled.
column3: But mrs Wilkins, after tugging agitatedly at a handkerchief that wouldn't come out of her pocket, did succeed at last in merely apparently blowing her nose with it, and then, blinking her eyes very quickly once or twice, looked at mrs Arbuthnot with a quivering air of half humble, half frightened apology, and smiled.

column2: Will you believe, she whispered, trying to steady her mouth, evidently dreadfully ashamed of herself, "that I've never spoken to any one before in my life like this?
column3: Will you believe, she whispered, trying to steady her mouth, evidently dreadfully ashamed of herself, "that I've never spoken to any one before in my life like this?

column2: I can't think, I simply don't know, what has come over me."
column3: I can't think, I simply don't know, what has come over me."

column2: It's the advertisement, said Mrs. Arbuthnot, nodding gravely.
column3: It's the advertisement, said mrs Arbuthnot, nodding gravely.

column2: Yes, said Mrs. Wilkins, dabbing furtively at her eyes, "and us both being so--"--she blew her nose again a little--"miserable."
column3: Yes, said mrs Wilkins, dabbing furtively at her eyes, "and us both being so-"--she blew her nose again a little-"miserable."

column2: Chapter 2
column3: Chapter two

column2: Of Course Mrs. Arbuthnot was not miserable--how could she be, she asked herself, when God was taking care of her?--but she let that pass for the moment unrepudiated, because of her conviction that here was another fellow-creature in urgent need of her help; and not just boots and blankets and better sanitary arrangements this time, but the more delicate help of comprehension, of finding the exact right words.
column3: Of Course mrs Arbuthnot was not miserable-how could she be, she asked herself, when God was taking care of her?--but she let that pass for the moment unrepudiated, because of her conviction that here was another fellow creature in urgent need of her help; and not just boots and blankets and better sanitary arrangements this time, but the more delicate help of comprehension, of finding the exact right words.

column2: The exact right words, she presently discovered, after trying various ones about living for others, and prayer, and the peace to be found in placing oneself unreservedly in God's hands--to meet all these words Mrs. Wilkins had other words, incoherent and yet, for the moment at least, till one had had more time, difficult to answer--the exact right words were a suggestion that it would do no harm to answer the advertisement.
column3: The exact right words, she presently discovered, after trying various ones about living for others, and prayer, and the peace to be found in placing oneself unreservedly in God's hands-to meet all these words mrs Wilkins had other words, incoherent and yet, for the moment at least, till one had had more time, difficult to answer-the exact right words were a suggestion that it would do no harm to answer the advertisement.

column2: Non-committal.
column3: Non committal.

column2: Mere inquiry.
column3: Mere inquiry.

column2: And what disturbed Mrs. Arbuthnot about this suggestion was that she did not make it solely to comfort Mrs. Wilkins; she made it because of her own strange longing for the mediaeval castle.
column3: And what disturbed mrs Arbuthnot about this suggestion was that she did not make it solely to comfort mrs Wilkins; she made it because of her own strange longing for the mediaeval castle.

column2: This was very disturbing.
column3: This was very disturbing.

column2: There she was, accustomed to direct, to lead, to advise, to support--except Frederick; she long since had learned to leave Frederick to God--being led herself, being influenced and thrown off her feet, by just an advertisement, by just an incoherent stranger.
column3: There she was, accustomed to direct, to lead, to advise, to support-except Frederick; she long since had learned to leave Frederick to God-being led herself, being influenced and thrown off her feet, by just an advertisement, by just an incoherent stranger.

column2: It was indeed disturbing.
column3: It was indeed disturbing.

column2: She failed to understand her sudden longing for what was, after all, self-indulgence, when for years no such desire had entered her heart.
column3: She failed to understand her sudden longing for what was, after all, self indulgence, when for years no such desire had entered her heart.

column2: There's no harm in simply asking, she said in a low voice, as if the vicar and the Savings Bank and all her waiting and dependent poor were listening and condemning.
column3: There's no harm in simply asking, she said in a low voice, as if the vicar and the Savings Bank and all her waiting and dependent poor were listening and condemning.

column2: It isn't as if it committed us to anything, said Mrs. Wilkins, also in a low voice, but her voice shook.
column3: It isn't as if it committed us to anything, said mrs Wilkins, also in a low voice, but her voice shook.

column2: They got up simultaneously--Mrs.
column3: They got up simultaneously-mrs

column2: Arbuthnot had a sensation of surprise that Mrs. Wilkins should be so tall--and went to a writing-table, and Mrs. Arbuthnot wrote to Z, Box 1000, The Times, for particulars.
column3: Arbuthnot had a sensation of surprise that mrs Wilkins should be so tall-and went to a writing table, and mrs Arbuthnot wrote to Z, Box one thousand, The Times, for particulars.

column2: She asked for all particulars, but the only one they really wanted was the one about the rent.
column3: She asked for all particulars, but the only one they really wanted was the one about the rent.

column2: They both felt that it was Mrs. Arbuthnot who ought to write the letter and do the business part.
column3: They both felt that it was mrs Arbuthnot who ought to write the letter and do the business part.

column2: Not only was she used to organizing and being practical, but she also was older, and certainly calmer; and she herself had no doubt too that she was wiser. Neither had Mrs. Wilkins any doubt of this; the very way Mrs. Arbuthnot parted her hair suggested a great calm that could only proceed from wisdom.
column3: Not only was she used to organizing and being practical, but she also was older, and certainly calmer; and she herself had no doubt too that she was wiser. Neither had mrs Wilkins any doubt of this; the very way mrs Arbuthnot parted her hair suggested a great calm that could only proceed from wisdom.

column2: But if she was wiser, older and calmer, Mrs. Arbuthnot's new friend nevertheless seemed to her to be the one who impelled. Incoherent, she yet impelled.
column3: But if she was wiser, older and calmer, mrs Arbuthnot's new friend nevertheless seemed to her to be the one who impelled. Incoherent, she yet impelled.

column2: She appeared to have, apart from her need of help, an upsetting kind of character.
column3: She appeared to have, apart from her need of help, an upsetting kind of character.

column2: She had a curious infectiousness.
column3: She had a curious infectiousness.

column2: She led one on.
column3: She led one on.

column2: And the way her unsteady mind leaped at conclusions--wrong ones, of course; witness the one that she, Mrs. Arbuthnot, was miserable--the way she leaped at conclusions was disconcerting.
column3: And the way her unsteady mind leaped at conclusions-wrong ones, of course; witness the one that she, mrs Arbuthnot, was miserable-the way she leaped at conclusions was disconcerting.

column2: Whatever she was, however, and whatever her unsteadiness, Mrs. Arbuthnot found herself sharing her excitement and her longing; and when the letter had been posted in the letter-box in the hall and actually was beyond getting back again, both she and Mrs. Wilkins felt the same sense of guilt.
column3: Whatever she was, however, and whatever her unsteadiness, mrs Arbuthnot found herself sharing her excitement and her longing; and when the letter had been posted in the letter box in the hall and actually was beyond getting back again, both she and mrs Wilkins felt the same sense of guilt.

column2: It only shows, said Mrs. Wilkins in a whisper, as they turned away from the letter-box, "how immaculately good we've been all our lives.
column3: It only shows, said mrs Wilkins in a whisper, as they turned away from the letter box, "how immaculately good we've been all our lives.

column2: The very first time we do anything our husbands don't know about we feel guilty."
column3: The very first time we do anything our husbands don't know about we feel guilty."

column2: I'm afraid I can't say I've been immaculately good, gently protested Mrs. Arbuthnot, a little uncomfortable at this fresh example of successful leaping at conclusions, for she had not said a word about her feeling of guilt.
column3: I'm afraid I can't say I've been immaculately good, gently protested mrs Arbuthnot, a little uncomfortable at this fresh example of successful leaping at conclusions, for she had not said a word about her feeling of guilt.

column2: Oh, but I'm sure you have--I see you being good--and that's why you're not happy.
column3: Oh, but I'm sure you have-I see you being good-and that's why you're not happy.

column2: She shouldn't say things like that, thought Mrs. Arbuthnot.
column3: She shouldn't say things like that, thought mrs Arbuthnot.

column2: I must try and help her not to.
column3: I must try and help her not to.

column2: Aloud she said gravely, "I don't know why you insist that I'm not happy.
column3: Aloud she said gravely, "I don't know why you insist that I'm not happy.

column2: When you know me better I think you'll find that I am.
column3: When you know me better I think you'll find that I am.

column2: And I'm sure you don't mean really that goodness, if one could attain it, makes one unhappy."
column3: And I'm sure you don't mean really that goodness, if one could attain it, makes one unhappy."

column2: Yes, I do, said Mrs. Wilkins.
column3: Yes, I do, said mrs Wilkins.

column2: Our sort of goodness does.	Our sort of goodness does.
column3: true

column2: We have attained it, and we are unhappy.
column3: We have attained it, and we are unhappy.

column2: There are miserable sorts of goodness and happy sorts--the sort we'll have at the mediaeval castle, for instance, is the happy sort."
column3: There are miserable sorts of goodness and happy sorts-the sort we'll have at the mediaeval castle, for instance, is the happy sort."

column2: That is, supposing we go there, said Mrs. Arbuthnot restrainingly.
column3: That is, supposing we go there, said mrs Arbuthnot restrainingly.

column2: She felt that Mrs. Wilkins needed holding on to. "After all, we've only written just to ask.
column3: She felt that mrs Wilkins needed holding on to. "After all, we've only written just to ask.

column2: Anybody may do that.
column3: Anybody may do that.

column2: I think it quite likely we shall find the conditions impossible, and even if they were not, probably by to-morrow we shall not want to go."
column3: I think it quite likely we shall find the conditions impossible, and even if they were not, probably by to morrow we shall not want to go."

column2: I see us there, was Mrs. Wilkins's answer to that.
column3: I see us there, was mrs Wilkins's answer to that.

column2: All this was very unbalancing.
column3: All this was very unbalancing.

column2: Mrs. Arbuthnot, as she presently splashed though the dripping streets on her way to a meeting she was to speak at, was in an unusually disturbed condition of mind.
column3: mrs Arbuthnot, as she presently splashed though the dripping streets on her way to a meeting she was to speak at, was in an unusually disturbed condition of mind.

column2: She had, she hoped, shown herself very calm to Mrs. Wilkins, very practical and sober, concealing her own excitement.
column3: She had, she hoped, shown herself very calm to mrs Wilkins, very practical and sober, concealing her own excitement.

column2: But she was really extraordinarily moved, and she felt happy, and she felt guilty, and she felt afraid, and she had all the feelings, though this she did not know, of a woman who was come away from a secret meeting with her lover.
column3: But she was really extraordinarily moved, and she felt happy, and she felt guilty, and she felt afraid, and she had all the feelings, though this she did not know, of a woman who was come away from a secret meeting with her lover.

column2: That, indeed, was what she looked like when she arrived late on her platform; she, the open-browed, looked almost furtive as her eyes fell on the staring wooden faces waiting to hear her try and persuade them to contribute to the alleviation of the urgent needs of the Hampstead poor, each one convinced that they needed contributions themselves.
column3: That, indeed, was what she looked like when she arrived late on her platform; she, the open browed, looked almost furtive as her eyes fell on the staring wooden faces waiting to hear her try and persuade them to contribute to the alleviation of the urgent needs of the Hampstead poor, each one convinced that they needed contributions themselves.

column2: She looked as though she were hiding something discreditable but delightful.
column3: She looked as though she were hiding something discreditable but delightful.

column2: Certainly her customary clear expression of candor was not there, and its place was taken by a kind of suppressed and frightened pleasedness, which would have led a more worldly-minded audience to the instant conviction of recent and probably impassioned lovemaking.
column3: Certainly her customary clear expression of candor was not there, and its place was taken by a kind of suppressed and frightened pleasedness, which would have led a more worldly minded audience to the instant conviction of recent and probably impassioned lovemaking.

column2: Beauty, beauty, beauty . . . the words kept ringing in her ears as she stood on the platform talking of sad things to the sparsely attended meeting.
column3: Beauty, beauty, beauty . . . the words kept ringing in her ears as she stood on the platform talking of sad things to the sparsely attended meeting.

column2: She had never been to Italy.
column3: She had never been to Italy.

column2: Was that really what her nest-egg was to be spent on after all?
column3: Was that really what her nest egg was to be spent on after all?

column2: Though she couldn't approve of the way Mrs. Wilkins was introducing the idea of predestination into her immediate future, just as if she had no choice, just as if to struggle, or even to reflect, were useless, it yet influenced her.
column3: Though she couldn't approve of the way mrs Wilkins was introducing the idea of predestination into her immediate future, just as if she had no choice, just as if to struggle, or even to reflect, were useless, it yet influenced her.

column2: Mrs. Wilkins's eyes had been the eyes of a seer.
column3: mrs Wilkins's eyes had been the eyes of a seer.

column2: Some people were like that, Mrs. Arbuthnot knew; and if Mrs. Wilkins had actually seen her at the mediaeval castle it did seem probable that struggling would be a waste of time.
column3: Some people were like that, mrs Arbuthnot knew; and if mrs Wilkins had actually seen her at the mediaeval castle it did seem probable that struggling would be a waste of time.

column2: Still, to spend her nest-egg on self-indulgence-- The origin of this egg had been corrupt, but she had at least supposed its end was to be creditable.
column3: Still, to spend her nest egg on self indulgence- The origin of this egg had been corrupt, but she had at least supposed its end was to be creditable.

column2: Was she to deflect it from its intended destination, which alone had appeared to justify her keeping it, and spend it on giving herself pleasure?
column3: Was she to deflect it from its intended destination, which alone had appeared to justify her keeping it, and spend it on giving herself pleasure?

column2: Mrs. Arbuthnot spoke on and on, so much practiced in the kind of speech that she could have said it all in her sleep, and at the end of the meeting, her eyes dazzled by her secret visions, she hardly noticed that nobody was moved in any way whatever, least of all in the way of contributions.
column3: mrs Arbuthnot spoke on and on, so much practiced in the kind of speech that she could have said it all in her sleep, and at the end of the meeting, her eyes dazzled by her secret visions, she hardly noticed that nobody was moved in any way whatever, least of all in the way of contributions.

column2: But the vicar noticed.
column3: But the vicar noticed.

column2: The vicar was disappointed.
column3: The vicar was disappointed.

column2: Usually his good friend and supporter Mrs. Arbuthnot succeeded better than this. And, what was even more unusual, she appeared, he observed, not even to mind.
column3: Usually his good friend and supporter mrs Arbuthnot succeeded better than this. And, what was even more unusual, she appeared, he observed, not even to mind.

column2: I can't imagine, he said to her as they parted, speaking irritably, for he was irritated both by the audience and by her, "what these people are coming to.
column3: I can't imagine, he said to her as they parted, speaking irritably, for he was irritated both by the audience and by her, "what these people are coming to.

column2: Nothing seems to move them."
column3: Nothing seems to move them."

column2: Perhaps they need a holiday, suggested Mrs. Arbuthnot; an unsatisfactory, a queer reply, the vicar thought.
column3: Perhaps they need a holiday, suggested mrs Arbuthnot; an unsatisfactory, a queer reply, the vicar thought.

column2: In February? he called after her sarcastically.
column3: In February? he called after her sarcastically.

column2: Oh no--not till April, said Mrs. Arbuthnot over her shoulder.
column3: Oh no-not till April, said mrs Arbuthnot over her shoulder.

column2: Very odd, thought the vicar.
column3: Very odd, thought the vicar.

column2: Very odd indeed. And he went home and was not perhaps quite Christian to his wife.
column3: Very odd indeed. And he went home and was not perhaps quite Christian to his wife.

column2: That night in her prayers Mrs. Arbuthnot asked for guidance.
column3: That night in her prayers mrs Arbuthnot asked for guidance.

column2: She felt she ought really to ask, straight out and roundly, that the mediaeval castle should already have been taken by some one else and the whole thing thus be settled, but her courage failed her.
column3: She felt she ought really to ask, straight out and roundly, that the mediaeval castle should already have been taken by some one else and the whole thing thus be settled, but her courage failed her.

column2: Suppose her prayer were to be answered?
column3: Suppose her prayer were to be answered?

column2: No; she couldn't ask it; she couldn't risk it.
column3: No; she couldn't ask it; she couldn't risk it.

column2: And after all--she almost pointed this out to God--if she spent her present nest-egg on a holiday she could quite soon accumulate another.
column3: And after all-she almost pointed this out to God-if she spent her present nest egg on a holiday she could quite soon accumulate another.

column2: Frederick pressed money on her; and it would only mean, while she rolled up a second egg, that for a time her contributions to the parish charities would be less.
column3: Frederick pressed money on her; and it would only mean, while she rolled up a second egg, that for a time her contributions to the parish charities would be less.

column2: And then it could be the next nest-egg whose original corruption would be purged away by the use to which it was finally put.
column3: And then it could be the next nest egg whose original corruption would be purged away by the use to which it was finally put.

column2: For Mrs. Arbuthnot, who had no money of her own, was obliged to live on the proceeds of Frederick's activities, and her very nest-egg was the fruit, posthumously ripened, of ancient sin.
column3: For mrs Arbuthnot, who had no money of her own, was obliged to live on the proceeds of Frederick's activities, and her very nest egg was the fruit, posthumously ripened, of ancient sin.

column2: The way Frederick made his living was one of the standing distresses of her life.
column3: The way Frederick made his living was one of the standing distresses of her life.

column2: He wrote immensely popular memoirs, regularly, every year, of the mistresses of kings.
column3: He wrote immensely popular memoirs, regularly, every year, of the mistresses of kings.

column2: There were in history numerous kings who had had mistresses, and there were still more numerous mistresses who had had kings; so that he had been able to publish a book of memoirs during each year of his married life, and even so there were greater further piles of these ladies waiting to be dealt with.
column3: There were in history numerous kings who had had mistresses, and there were still more numerous mistresses who had had kings; so that he had been able to publish a book of memoirs during each year of his married life, and even so there were greater further piles of these ladies waiting to be dealt with.

column2: Mrs. Arbuthnot was helpless.
column3: mrs Arbuthnot was helpless.

column2: Whether she liked it or not, she was obliged to live on the proceeds.
column3: Whether she liked it or not, she was obliged to live on the proceeds.

column2: He gave her a dreadful sofa once, after the success of his Du Barri memoir, with swollen cushions and soft, receptive lap, and it seemed to her a miserable thing that there, in her very home, should flaunt this re-incarnation of a dead old French sinner.
column3: He gave her a dreadful sofa once, after the success of his Du Barri memoir, with swollen cushions and soft, receptive lap, and it seemed to her a miserable thing that there, in her very home, should flaunt this re incarnation of a dead old French sinner.

column2: Simply good, convinced that morality is the basis of happiness, the fact that she and Frederick should draw their sustenance from guilt, however much purged by the passage of centuries, was one of the secret reasons of her sadness.
column3: Simply good, convinced that morality is the basis of happiness, the fact that she and Frederick should draw their sustenance from guilt, however much purged by the passage of centuries, was one of the secret reasons of her sadness.

column2: The more the memoired lady had forgotten herself, the more his book about her was read and the more free-handed he was to his wife; and all that he gave her was spent, after adding slightly to her nest-egg--for she did hope and believe that some day people would cease to want to read of wickedness, and then Frederick would need supporting--on helping the poor.
column3: The more the memoired lady had forgotten herself, the more his book about her was read and the more free handed he was to his wife; and all that he gave her was spent, after adding slightly to her nest egg-for she did hope and believe that some day people would cease to want to read of wickedness, and then Frederick would need supporting-on helping the poor.

column2: The parish flourished because, to take a handful at random, of the ill-behavior of the ladies Du Barri, Montespan, Pompadour, Ninon de l'Enclos, and even of learned Maintenon.
column3: The parish flourished because, to take a handful at random, of the ill behavior of the ladies Du Barri, Montespan, Pompadour, Ninon de l'Enclos, and even of learned Maintenon.

column2: The poor were the filter through which the money was passed, to come out, Mrs. Arbuthnot hoped, purified.
column3: The poor were the filter through which the money was passed, to come out, mrs Arbuthnot hoped, purified.

column2: She could do no more.
column3: She could do no more.

column2: She had tried in days gone by to think the situation out, to discover the exact right course for her to take, but had found it, as she had found Frederick, too difficult, and had left it, as she had left Frederick, to God.
column3: She had tried in days gone by to think the situation out, to discover the exact right course for her to take, but had found it, as she had found Frederick, too difficult, and had left it, as she had left Frederick, to God.

column2: Nothing of this money was spent on her house or dress; those remained, except for the great soft sofa, austere.
column3: Nothing of this money was spent on her house or dress; those remained, except for the great soft sofa, austere.

column2: It was the poor who profited.
column3: It was the poor who profited.

column2: Their very boots were stout with sins.
column3: Their very boots were stout with sins.

column2: But how difficult it had been.
column3: But how difficult it had been.

column2: Mrs. Arbuthnot, groping for guidance, prayed about it to exhaustion.
column3: mrs Arbuthnot, groping for guidance, prayed about it to exhaustion.

column2: Ought she perhaps to refuse to touch the money, to avoid it as she would have avoided the sins which were its source?
column3: Ought she perhaps to refuse to touch the money, to avoid it as she would have avoided the sins which were its source?

column2: But then what about the parish's boots?
column3: But then what about the parish's boots?

column2: She asked the vicar what he thought, and through much delicate language, evasive and cautious, it did finally appear that he was for the boots.
column3: She asked the vicar what he thought, and through much delicate language, evasive and cautious, it did finally appear that he was for the boots.

column2: At least she had persuaded Frederick, when first he began his terrible successful career--he only began it after their marriage; when she married him he had been a blameless official attached to the library of the British Museum--to publish the memoirs under another name, so that she was not publicly branded.
column3: At least she had persuaded Frederick, when first he began his terrible successful career-he only began it after their marriage; when she married him he had been a blameless official attached to the library of the British Museum-to publish the memoirs under another name, so that she was not publicly branded.

column2: Hampstead read the books with glee, and had no idea that their writer lived in its midst. Frederick was almost unknown, even by sight, in Hampstead.
column3: Hampstead read the books with glee, and had no idea that their writer lived in its midst. Frederick was almost unknown, even by sight, in Hampstead.

column2: He never went to any of its gatherings.
column3: He never went to any of its gatherings.

column2: Whatever it was he did in the way of recreation was done in London, but he never spoke of what he did or whom he saw; he might have been perfectly friendless for any mention he ever made of friends to his wife.
column3: Whatever it was he did in the way of recreation was done in London, but he never spoke of what he did or whom he saw; he might have been perfectly friendless for any mention he ever made of friends to his wife.

column2: Only the vicar knew where the money for the parish came from, and he regarded it, he told Mrs. Arbuthnot, as a matter of honour not to mention it.
column3: Only the vicar knew where the money for the parish came from, and he regarded it, he told mrs Arbuthnot, as a matter of honour not to mention it.

column2: And at least her little house was not haunted by the loose lived ladies, for Frederick did his work away from home.
column3: And at least her little house was not haunted by the loose lived ladies, for Frederick did his work away from home.

column2: He had two rooms near the British Museum, which was the scene of his exhumations, and there he went every morning, and he came back long after his wife was asleep.
column3: He had two rooms near the British Museum, which was the scene of his exhumations, and there he went every morning, and he came back long after his wife was asleep.

column2: Sometimes he did not come back at all.
column3: Sometimes he did not come back at all.

column2: Sometimes she did not see him for several days together.
column3: Sometimes she did not see him for several days together.

column2: Then he would suddenly appear at breakfast, having let himself in with his latchkey the night before, very jovial and good-natured and free-handed and glad if she would allow him to give her something--a well-fed man, contented with the world; a jolly, full-blooded, satisfied man.
column3: Then he would suddenly appear at breakfast, having let himself in with his latchkey the night before, very jovial and good-natured and free handed and glad if she would allow him to give her something-a well fed man, contented with the world; a jolly, full blooded, satisfied man.

column2: And she was always gentle, and anxious that his coffee should be as he liked it.
column3: And she was always gentle, and anxious that his coffee should be as he liked it.

column2: He seemed very happy.
column3: He seemed very happy.

column2: Life, she often thought, however much one tabulated was yet a mystery.
column3: Life, she often thought, however much one tabulated was yet a mystery.

column2: There were always some people it was impossible to place.
column3: There were always some people it was impossible to place.

column2: Frederick was one of them.
column3: Frederick was one of them.

column2: He didn't seem to bear the remotest resemblance to the original Frederick.
column3: He didn't seem to bear the remotest resemblance to the original Frederick.

column2: He didn't seem to have the least need of any of the things he used to say were so important and beautiful--love, home, complete communion of thoughts, complete immersion in each other's interests.
column3: He didn't seem to have the least need of any of the things he used to say were so important and beautiful-love, home, complete communion of thoughts, complete immersion in each other's interests.

column2: After those early painful attempts to hold him up to the point from which they had hand in hand so splendidly started, attempts in which she herself had got terribly hurt and the Frederick she supposed she had married was mangled out of recognition, she hung him up finally by her bedside as the chief subject of her prayers, and left him, except for those, entirely to God.
column3: After those early painful attempts to hold him up to the point from which they had hand in hand so splendidly started, attempts in which she herself had got terribly hurt and the Frederick she supposed she had married was mangled out of recognition, she hung him up finally by her bedside as the chief subject of her prayers, and left him, except for those, entirely to God.

column2: She had loved Frederick too deeply to be able now to do anything but pray for him.
column3: She had loved Frederick too deeply to be able now to do anything but pray for him.

column2: He had no idea that he never went out of the house without her blessing going with him too, hovering, like a little echo of finished love, round that once dear head.
column3: He had no idea that he never went out of the house without her blessing going with him too, hovering, like a little echo of finished love, round that once dear head.

column2: She didn't dare think of him as he used to be, as he had seemed to her to be in those marvelous first days of their love-making, of their marriage. Her child had died; she had nothing, nobody of her own to lavish herself on.
column3: She didn't dare think of him as he used to be, as he had seemed to her to be in those marvelous first days of their love making, of their marriage. Her child had died; she had nothing, nobody of her own to lavish herself on.

column2: The poor became her children, and God the object of her love.
column3: The poor became her children, and God the object of her love.

column2: What could be happier than such a life, she sometimes asked herself; but her face, and particularly her eyes, continued sad.
column3: What could be happier than such a life, she sometimes asked herself; but her face, and particularly her eyes, continued sad.
